column5: A couple of questions: How much mono backing should I use on my spinning reel before attaching fireline? Also, what type of know do you use for the connection.Thanks for the help.
Bob,You only need enough mono to cover the bottom of the spool. I always connect the Fireline to the mono with back to back uni knots. Good Luck!Fred
Don't bother with the mono. Put 2 wraps of black tape around the spool first.

You can go with little or none, as has been suggested. I think of the mono as more than just backing, however. The mono cuts down the amount of Fireline you need to put on. With 10/4 Fireline, a 2000 series reel can hold more than 150 yards of the stuff. That can get expensive. So, I use enough mono so that 50-70 yards of Fireline comfortably sits on the spool.derrek.CANADIAN WALLEYE OPEN UP AND SAY "EH"!
Is that black electrician tape ?(its glossy ?) or do you mean black friction tape like used for hockey sticks ????thanksjake
You can use black tape.But what i do is i will wrap the fireline by hand a few times around the spool really tight.Then you won't have any slipping problems.FISH ON.

I agree with Peanut in post #3 especially for jigging, Lindy Rigging, and bottom bouncing applications. For trolling reels I use 100-125 yds of fireline and after 2-3 seasons I reverse the line by spooling the fireline onto a different reel. I keep track with a small sticker on reel seat. This way I have fresh line closest to baits and save extra $$$ for more fishing toys. :D

Use elastic bands instead of tape that leaves sticky reisdue. All you are doing is covering some/most of the spool so the line won't spin. I hand wind mine tight in the beginning like stated above by N.Manitoba and don't have the problem. I do have two reels with elastic bands and never had the problem with them either.Stay off the pipe...and don't forget to wipe.Red
